entity: United Nations Regional Centre for Preventive Diplomacy for Central Asia
entity_raw_name: 3.	United Nations Regional Centre for Preventive Diplomacy for Central Asia
source_file: A_80_6 (SECT. 3)_ADD.4_CLUSTER_III_FASCICLE ADVANCE UNEDITED COPY FOR ACABQ.json

content.text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024

children.text: Overall orientation
Mandates and background

The United Nations Regional Centre for Preventive Diplomacy for Central Asia is responsible for supporting national authorities in identifying and addressing threats to regional peace and security. The open-ended mandate was defined through an exchange of letters between the Secretary-General and the President of the Security Council (S/2007/279 and S/2007/280). The mission plays a central role in preventive diplomacy in Central Asia and provides a platform for regional dialogue on the pressing challenges to security and stability.

The main function of the Centre is to strengthen United Nations capacity for conflict prevention in Central Asia through liaising with the Governments and, with their concurrence, engaging with the parties concerned on promoting preventive diplomacy; monitoring and analysing the situation on the ground, providing the Secretary-General with updates relating to conflict prevention; maintaining contact with regional organizations, encouraging their peacemaking efforts and facilitating coordination and information exchange, with due regard to their specific mandates; providing a political framework and leadership for preventive activities of the United Nations country teams and supporting efforts of the resident coordinators and representatives of the United Nations system, in promoting an integrated approach to preventive diplomacy and humanitarian assistance; and maintaining close contact with the United Nations Assistance Mission in Afghanistan (UNAMA) to ensure a comprehensive analysis of the situation in the wider region.

The Regional Centre’s current work is guided by a five-year programme of action for the period 2021–2025, which was adopted at the annual meeting of deputy ministers for foreign affairs in December 2020. The new programme of action 2026-2030 will be adopted at the end of 2025.
Programme of work
Objective
The objective, to which this mission contributes, is to enhance regional security and stability in Central Asia.
Strategy and external factors for 2026
To contribute to the objective, the mission will:

Carry out good offices functions for preventive diplomacy in Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan, as well as monitor and analyse regional developments, while maintaining contact with regional organizations and other parts of the United Nations system;

Organize an annual meeting of deputy ministers for foreign affairs of Central Asia and convene expert forums to advise the annual consultative meetings of the Central Asian Heads of State. The Regional Centre will also promote political participation of women through the engagement of senior women political leaders in the Central Asia Women Leaders’ Caucus regional platform;

Promote arrangements on transboundary water management in the region, support initiatives and dialogue on water, energy and environmental and climate cooperation, and help to address challenges relating to transboundary water and climate change;

Implement the joint project with the Office of Counter-Terrorism on the basis of the latest Joint Plan of Action for the implementation of the United Nations Global Counter-Terrorism Strategy in Central Asia. In addition, through the Preventive Diplomacy Academy project, the Centre will continue its efforts to engage young people; and

Support the Central Asian States in addressing emerging threats to security and stability, as well as the other external risk factors, including the complex situation in Afghanistan and developments regarding the construction of the Qush-Tepa Canal.
The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:

Improved regional cooperation in addressing transnational threats of terrorism, violent extremism conducive to terrorism, drug trafficking and organized crime, as well as coping with regional challenges concerning the management of water resources and climate change; and

Political will to sustain the progress of the Governments of the Central Asian States regarding deeper engagements in promoting peace and stability through enhanced cooperation and trust-building in the region, including on high-level platforms such as the consultative meeting of Heads of State.

Regarding cooperation with other entities, the mission maintains contact with the Commonwealth of Independent States, the European Union, the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe and the Shanghai Cooperation Organization, as well as other organizations, such as the International Fund for Saving the Aral Sea (IFAS). The Centre continues exchanges with the Conference on Interaction and Confidence-building Measures in Asia and the Collective Security Treaty Organization on topics of common interest. It cooperates with relevant actors, including international financial institutions such as the World Bank.

With regard to inter-agency coordination, the Centre cooperates closely with the resident coordinators in the five countries, the Development Coordination Office and the entities represented in the United Nations country teams, including UNDP, the UN Women, UNODC, UNOCT, UNESCO, ECE and ESCAP. The mission regularly shares information and coordinates activities with the UNAMA.
With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:
The continued commitment by five Governments of the region to preventive diplomacy and regional cooperation; and

The five countries of the region continue to monitor developments in Afghanistan and enhance preparedness to potential threats and risks of violent extremism and terrorism, drug trafficking and a potential humanitarian crisis. They continue to provide and advocate for humanitarian assistance to Afghanistan.

The UNRCCA integrates a gender perspective into operational and programmatic activities, deliverables and results, as appropriate. It encourages the countries to ensure gender balance in their delegations and include gender-related issues in the agendas of regional expert-level workshops on preventive diplomacy and confidence-building for the states’ officials.
Programme performance in 2024
Constructive and strengthened relations among the Central Asian States in specific areas

The Regional Centre contributed to regional security and stability through continuous engagement with five Member States on issues of shared concern for the region, including the potential impact of the situation in Afghanistan on water and climate in the region. In 2024, the Counter-Terrorism Early Warning Network for Central Asia was operationalised, contributing to improved exchange of information and coordination among various national and regional entities. The Regional Expert Council on Returnees from the conflict zones was launched. The Central Asia Women Leaders’ Caucus has strengthened its engagement on the situation of women and girls in Afghanistan. The mission continued to promote the Youth, Peace and Security agenda by strengthening the regional Alumni network of the Preventive Diplomacy Academy participants and advancing the Youth-governments dialogue.
Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 16).
Table 16 – Performance measure

table_content.text: Enhanced regional security and stability in Central Asia through more inclusive and open discussions and new initiatives of the countries of the region and the Regional Centre
Strengthened regional cooperation in Central Asia, initiatives promoting peace and trust in the region and more inclusive regional platforms to discuss issues of shared concern

Strengthened regional cooperation in Central Asia, with initiatives that promote peace and trust in the region and more inclusive regional platforms to exchange information and best practices, and the development of recommendations on issues of mutual concern

children.text: Planned result for 2026
Enhanced regional interaction in Central Asia to address current and emerging risks and threats to peace and security – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

In 2024, the mission contributed to enhanced regional security and stability in Central Asia through preventive diplomacy by supporting action to promote trust and cooperation in the region through more inclusive dialogue and partnerships, which met the planned target.
Lessons learned and planned change

The in-person exchanges among counterparts proved to gain meaningful outcomes. In applying this lesson, the mission will strive to conduct meetings, as well as support regional platforms such as the International Fund for Saving the Aral Sea, including participation in various regional events.
Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see table 17).
Table 17 – Performance measure

table_content.text: Enhanced                                                                                                                                                                            regional security and stability in Central Asia by promoting peace and trust in the region through inclusive and open discussions and new initiatives of the States of the region and the Centre
Enhanced regional interaction in Central Asia to address threats to peace and security through initiatives aimed at promoting peace and trust and inclusive regional platforms

The Regional Centre contributes to an enhancement of regional interaction in Central Asia to address threats to regional peace and security through initiatives aimed at promoting peace and trust and creating inclusive regional platforms
Strengthened regional peace and security in the Central Asian States through enhanced partnerships, dialogue, and trust-building on the basis of the countries’ needs and initiatives

Deeper engagements in the Central Asian States through enhanced partnerships, dialogue, in promoting peace and stability, enhanced cooperation and trust-building in the region, including on high-level platforms such as Central Asian Women Leaders Caucus and Deputy Foreign Ministers meetings

content.text: B.	 Proposed post and non-post resource requirements for 2026

children.text: Resource requirements (regular budget) – Table 19 – Financial resources
(Thousands of United States dollars)
Table 20 – Human resources

The proposed resource requirements for 2026 for the Regional Centre amount to $3,458,800 (net of staff assessment) and would provide for salaries and common staff costs $2,711,200 for the continuation of 30 posts (1 Assistant Secretary-General, 1 P-5, 2 P-4, 2 P-3, 2 Field Service, 4 National Professional Officer and 18 Local level), as well as operational costs of $747,600, comprising the costs for consultants and consulting services ($16,800), official travel ($230,100), facilities and infrastructure ($90,800), ground transportation ($29,100), communications and information technology ($211,800), medical supplies ($2,100) and other supplies, services and equipment ($166,900).

For 2026, no change is proposed to the number and levels of the posts. A vacancy rate of zero per cent has been applied to the estimates for international staff and National Professional Officers, based on the actual average vacancy rates in 2024, and vacancy rate of zero per cent has been applied to the estimates for Local level staff taking into account the actual vacancy rates in March 2025.

The decrease in requirements for 2026 compared with the appropriation for 2025 is attributable primarily to: (a) decreased requirements for international staff due to lower estimated common staff costs (estimated common staff costs as a percentage of salary costs of 42.0 per cent compared to 51.5 per cent in the 2025 budget) based on past expenditure; (b) decreased requirements for facilities and infrastructure and communication and information technology, due to lower acquisition of furniture and equipment including communication and information technology equipment. The decreased requirements are offset in part by: (a) increased requirements for national staff owing primarily to higher estimated higher common staff costs for Local level staff (estimated common staff costs as a percentage of salary costs of 37.0 per cent compared to 32.7 per cent in the 2025 budget); and (b) increased requirements under the other supplies, services and equipment class of expenditure for individual contractual services to support mandated priorities in the areas preventive diplomacy related to youth, peace, and security, particularly the Preventive Diplomacy Academy initiative in Central Asia.
Extrabudgetary resources

In 2025, extrabudgetary resources in the amount of $248,000 were projected for the project for Central Asian regional cooperation on transboundary water management, with an updated scope of activities, and for support for the Women Leaders’ Caucus to provide influential leadership on the issues pertaining to gender equality, woman and peace and security and women’s empowerment within and among the countries of the region. Many of the meetings were held in a hybrid format.

In 2026, extrabudgetary resources in the amount of $185,000 are projected, to continue to support the Women Leaders’ Caucus in providing influential leadership on women’s engagement in the countries of the region, as well as activities under the preventive diplomacy academy project, and the Centre’s strategy in support of water, energy and environmental and climate cooperation in the region for the period 2026–2030.
The increase in the estimates projected for 2026 compared with the estimates for 2025 is attributable primarily to the increased travel requirements for in-person and hybrid-format meetings.
